thread.title: Chris Young pitches Royals past Twins 3-1
thread.title_full: Chris Young pitches Royals past Twins 3-1

title: Chris Young pitches Royals past Twins 3-1
text:
With 6-plus strong innings, Chris Young pitches Royals past Twins 3-1 in push for home field By ANDRES YBARRA Associated Press   1:00   1:00   
Minnesota (434) 

MINNEAPOLIS â€” After watching Chris Young strike out the side in the sixth inning, Kansas City Royals manager Ned Yost approached his starter in the dugout to tell him he was nearing his pitch limit. 
"I just told him I'd give him what I had," the 36-year-old right-hander said. 
After an emotional rollercoaster of a week in which his team clinched the AL Central and his father died, Young has certainly given the Royals a lot while making a bid to be part of their postseason rotation. 
Young pitched into the seventh Friday night for his second outstanding start since returning from the bullpen, allowing one run for the Royals in their 3-1 victory over the Minnesota Twins . 
He yielded four hits in 6 1-3 innings, retiring 15 of 16 batters during one stretch. 
Ben Zobrist put a major dent in Minnesota's postseason plans with an RBI double in the eighth inning against struggling All-Star Glen Perkins. 
"Great team win, great environment," Young said. "The weather, the sun setting early, it's a fun time of year and it's fun to be a part of it." 
Eight days ago, the Royals became AL Central champions for the first time, clinching their first division title in 30 years and ensuring a drama-free final week. They went into the weekend trying to earn home-field advantage throughout the postseason, and are currently tied with Toronto for the top record in the league. 
It certainly hasn't been drama-free for Young, who last pitched in the playoffs nine years ago with San Diego. 
"I haven't thought about it that much really," Young said about ending his personal postseason drought. "Just trying to get through the last week, and it's been an emotional rollercoaster for me." 
In three starts against the Twins this season, Young allowed just two runs and 11 hits in 18 innings. In the sixth, he walked to the mound preparing to face sluggers Miguel Sano, Trevor Plouffe and Eddie Rosario. Young struck out all three swinging. 
"Obviously, it was big for us to get another inning under his belt, save the bullpen a little bit," catcher Drew Butera said. "He just had good deception today." 
Louis Coleman (1-0), Ryan Madson and Wade Davis wrapped up the win, with Davis notching his 16th save in 17 attempts. 
The Twins began the day trailing Houston by one game and tied with Los Angeles in the AL wild-card race, and with only two days left to make up ground this was as devastating a defeat as they've had in 2015. The Angels beat Texas, pulling ahead of the Twins, and the Astros played later at Arizona. 
Perkins, hampered by neck and back trouble that led to his removal from the closer role, spoiled a stellar start by Ervin Santana (7-5) with a first-pitch fastball that Zobrist drove off the wall in right-center field. Zobrist then scored when right fielder Torii Hunter fumbled a single by Mike Moustakas, another blemish on an awful second half for Perkins. 
FOURTH STARTER? 
Should the Royals make it past the Division Series, Yost will likely need to decide between Young and lefty Kris Medlen to round out his rotation. The manager wasn't about to show his hand on Friday, though. 
"I've already got it figured out," he said with a grin. 
SWEET RELIEF 
Madson induced All-Star Brian Dozier into a key double play in the eighth when he relieved Coleman. Eduardo Escobar led off the inning with a single before Dozier came to the plate. After a single by Joe Mauer, Madson struck out Sano swinging. 
"Especially with that tight of a ballgame with the hitters that are coming up, those guys kind of smell blood once something gets going, so it's nice to just nip it right away," Madson said. 
TRAINER'S ROOM 
Three banged-up regulars were held out of the Royals' lineup, with CF Lorenzo Cain (knee), DH Kendrys Morales (quadriceps) and C Salvador Perez (thumb) on the bench, but Yost said he wasn't worried. Cain should be ready to play Saturday, Morales was available to pinch hit and Perez was rested with the afternoon game next. 
UP NEXT 
Royals: RHP Yordano Ventura (12-8, 4.20 ERA) will start on Saturday. He's 8-1 with a 3.26 ERA and 81 strikeouts in 80 innings over his last 13 turns, and the only loss in that stretch was to the Twins at home on Sept. 7. 
Twins: LHP Tommy Milone (9-5, 4.04) will take the mound in the middle game of the series, coming off a critical win at Cleveland on Monday following an 11-day break due to weakness around his shoulder.
